summary: This document is an email chain from September 22, 2020, discussing technical issues with producing discovery files to Ghislaine Maxwell at the Metropolitan Detention Center (MDC). The chain includes a forwarded letter from defense attorney Christian Everdell regarding Maxwell's access to documents.

persons.name: Christian Everdell
persons.context: Attorney at Cohen & Gresser LLP who sent a letter regarding Ghislaine Maxwell's access to discovery documents. His signature block is included.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The subject of the forwarded letter, an accused individual detained at MDC who is having issues accessing certain discovery file types.

persons.name: Mark S. Cohen
persons.context: Attorney at Cohen & Gresser LLP copied on the original letter from Christian Everdell.

persons.name: Laura Menninger
persons.context: Attorney at Cohen & Gresser LLP copied on the original letter from Christian Everdell.

persons.name: Bob Pagliuca
persons.context: Attorney at Cohen & Gresser LLP copied on the original letter from Christian Everdell.

events.title: Email Chain on Discovery File Access
events.description: A series of emails discussing technical problems with Ghislaine Maxwell accessing certain discovery file types (Excel, load files, EML files) on her computer at MDC.

keyFacts: Ghislaine Maxwell was experiencing technical difficulties accessing discovery files (Excel, load files, EML files) on her computer at the Metropolitan Detention Center.
The defense team, including Christian Everdell, was actively working with prosecution contractors to resolve the file access issue, suggesting converting files to PDF.
The email chain reveals logistical challenges in providing discovery to a high-profile detainee and the involvement of technical contractors for the U.S. Attorney's Office.
The correspondence includes a forwarded letter from defense attorney Christian Everdell of Cohen & Gresser LLP, indicating formal legal communication regarding Maxwell's case.
